questions.question:
Question 1: A middle-aged woman with resistant intractable back pain is planned to receive neuraxial 
opioids for analgesia. Which of the following is the site of action of this drug in the spinal 
cord?

options.d: No spinal component is seen with opioid analgesia

questions.explanation:
The spinal component of opioid analgesia is seen due to the action in the dorsal horn of the spinal 
cord. Opioid analgesia: • Spinal component: opioids act in the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn to inhibit the 
release of excitatory transmitters like substance P from primary afferents carrying pain 
impulses. This action is through interneurons that are involved in the gating of pain impulses. • Supraspinal component: action at the medulla, periaqueductal gray matter, limbic, and cortical 
areas alter the processing and interpretation of pain impulses. It also sends inhibitory impulses 
through descending pathways to the spinal cord. • Peripheral action: acts on small primary afferent terminals in the skin or deeper structures, 
decreasing their sensitization following tissue injury.

questions.question:
Question 2: A primigravida in labor is administered opioids for epidural analgesia. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding the drug administered?

options.a: Act on dorsal horn substantia gelatinosa
options.c: Function of the GIT is not affected

questions.explanation:
Gastrointestinal motility is decreased by epidural opioids. Option A: The epidural opioids provide more direct access to the first pain-processing synapse i.e., 
substantia gelatinosa by acting on the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. Option B: Symptoms such as pruritus, nausea, and vomiting are also common with the epidural 
route. Option D: Respiratory depression is seen with epidural opioids but the incidence is lesser than the 
parenteral route. 365 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient is receiving morphine for pain management. Which of the following findings would 
you not expect?
questions.explanation: Miosis (not mydriasis) would be expected in a patient receiving morphine. Opioids stimulate the Edinger-Westphal nucleus of the III cranial nerve resulting in miosis. Urinary retention, vomiting, and pruritus are actions of opiates.

questions.question:
Question 4: 359 
Sold by @itachibot An experimental drug that acts only as an agonist at the mu-opioid receptor is being 
developed. Which of the following effects would be seen with this drug?
questions.explanation: Mu opioid receptor activation results in miosis, nausea, and vomiting. Mu receptor actions (mnemonic- MUSCARINE): • Miosis • Urine retention • Sedation • Constipation • Analgesia • Respiratory depression • Increased muscular rigidity • Negative bile flow (contraction of the sphincter of Oddi) • Euphoria

questions.question: Question 5: Dysphoria is mediated by which opioid receptor?
questions.explanation: Dysphoria is mediated by kappa opioid receptor. ‹appa receptor actions: • Dysphoria, psychotomimetic • Analgesia (Spinal and supraspinal) • Miosis • Sedation • Physical dependence • Reduced GI motility

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient is administered intravenous opioids for postoperative pain management. This drug 
elicits its analgesic action through which of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
366 
Sold by @itachibot Analgesia produced by opioids is mediated by µ (mu), k (kappa), and  (delta) receptors. Opioid 
receptors are part of the G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) family. Supraspinal analgesia is predominantly mediated by the µ1 receptor and spinal analgesia by the k 
and  receptor.

questions.question:
Question 7: Following surgery, a woman received multiple doses of intravenous opioids for pain 
management. Later, her respiratory rate became 8 per minute. Which receptor mediates this 
adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
The given features suggest opioid-induced respiratory depression, which is mediated by the action 
of opioids on µ receptors (µ2) in the brainstem respiratory centers. Drug of choice for opioid-induced respiratory depression is naloxone.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following drugs does not aggravate opioid-induced respiratory depression?
questions.explanation:
Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by 
opioids. Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with CNS depressant substances 
like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative hypnotics.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is an opiate?
questions.explanation:
Morphine is an opiate. The term opiate specifically describes the naturally occurring alkaloids: morphine, codeine, 
thebaine, and papaverine. Options A and C: Pentazocine and fentanyl are synthetic opioids. Option B: Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the other name for diacetylmorphine?
questions.explanation:
Heroin is structurally diacetylmorphine. It is more potent than morphine and causes more euphoric effects. It is banned in some countries. Diacetylmorphine is converted into monoacetylmorphine and morphine, to which the 
pharmacological actions of heroin are mainly attributed. Monoacetylmorphine is more 
lipid-soluble than morphine. Codeine is also known as methyl morphine. Meperidine is also known as pethidine. 367 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient who has a history of substance abuse with a semisynthetic opioid is now referred to 
a rehabilitation center. Which of the following drugs is he likely addicted to?
questions.explanation: He is likely addicted to heroin as it is the only semisynthetic opioid among the given options. Morphine, codeine, and thebaine are natural opioids derived from poppy Papaver somniferum.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 24-year-old pregnant woman is in labor. Your senior administered her a synthetic opioid to 
provide labor analgesia. Which of the following would be the drug administered to her?
questions.explanation:
Butorphanol would be the drug administered to her as it is the only synthetic opioid among the 
given options. Heroin, dihydromorphone, and buprenorphine are semisynthetic opioids.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 54-year-old woman is receiving acupuncture treatment for her back pain. Which of the 
following opioid peptides does not mediate analgesia in her?
questions.explanation:
Morphine does not mediate analgesia in acupuncture as it is not an endogenous opioid. It is a 
naturally occurring opioid derived from poppy Papaver somniferum. One of the most accepted mechanisms of action of acupuncture is that it works by releasing 
endogenous opioid peptides resulting in analgesia. Endogenous opioid peptides are produced 
physiologically in the body and act through an opioid receptor. Endogenous opioid peptides: • Enkephalins (more potent at  receptor) • -endorphins (more potent at  receptor) • Dynorphins (more potent at  receptor) • Orphanin FQ or Nociceptin • Neoendorphins • Endomorphins

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with biliary colic. The intern has administered an analgesic, following 
which the pain got aggravated. Which of the following could be responsible for the 
aggravation of the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Morphine is the analgesic which could be responsible for the aggravation of the patient's 
symptoms. It causes constriction of the sphincter of Oddi causing an increase in fluid pressure in the 
common bile duct and gall bladder. Note: Pethidine causes lesser spasm of the sphincter of Oddi and can be used in biliary colic.

questions.question:
Question 15: You decide to administer morphine for analgesia in your patients. In which of the following 
patients would you avoid morphine?

options.a: A 50 year old man with hypotension
options.b: A 32 year old woman with head injury
options.c: A 44 year old woman with hypothyroidism
options.d: A 21 year old man with type 1 diabetes mellitus

questions.explanation:
368 
Sold by @itachibot Morphine should be avoided in a patient with head injury because: • Morphine retains CO2 that increases intracranial pressure (ICP) and adds to the already 
increased ICP. • Therapeutic doses can result in marked respiratory depression. • Interferes with the assessment of progress by causing miosis, vomiting, and altered mentation. Among the above options, head injury seems to be the most appropriate answer and some 
authorities consider head injury as a contraindication. Option A: Hypotension can increase the susceptibility to vasodilating effects of morphine. Caution 
needs to be exercised. Option C: Sensitivity to opioids is increased in hypothyroidism. Caution needs to be exercised. Option D: Diabetes is not a contraindication for morphine use.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements are true?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1, 2, 3 & 5 are true. Option 1: Morphine is used in pulmonary edema due to its vasodilatory and anxiolytic actions. Option 2: Morphine should be avoided as it causes constriction of the sphincter of Oddi causing 
an increase in fluid pressure in the common bile duct and gall bladder. Pethidine causes lesser 
spasm of the sphincter of Oddi and can be used in biliary colic. Option 3: Indomethacin is an NSAID used in headache. Option 4: The use of aspirin can worsen peptic ulcer disease. Option 5: Single dose of pethidine (meperidine) can be effective in the treatment of postanesthetic 
shivering.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma after a road traffic accident. He was 
given IV morphine for pain relief following which he developed respiratory difficulty. What 
could be the most likely cause?

options.b: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.explanation:
The most likely cause of respiratory difficulty in the given clinical scenario is CO2 retention due to 
opioid use, as the patient was administered morphine after head trauma. Head injury is considered as a contraindication to morphine use because: • Morphine retains CO2 that increases intracranial pressure (ICP) and adds to the already 
increased ICP. • Therapeutic doses can result in marked respiratory depression. • Interferes with the assessment of progress by causing miosis, vomiting, and altered mentation.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine?
questions.explanation:
369 
Sold by @itachibot Acute myocardial infarction is not a contraindication for morphine use. Morphine is the opioid of choice for myocardial infarction as it relieves anxiety, chest pain, and 
myocardial oxygen demand. Contraindications to the use of Morphine: • Bronchial asthma: Histamine release can cause bronchoconstriction and precipitate attacks of 
asthma. • Renal failure: Morphine-6-glucuronide (metabolite) can accumulate and lead to prolonged 
respiratory depression. • Emphysema: Respiratory depression and decreased response to hypoxia can cause hypercapnia 
in patients with COPD • Head injury: Hypercapnia due to respiratory depression can increase ICP. Miosis, vomiting, and 
effect on wakefulness make interpreting the signs of head injury difficult. • Biliary colic: Constriction of sphincter of Oddi can worsen biliary spasm • Hypotension and shock

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about the WHO analgesic ladder for chronic pain in adults?

options.b: Adjuvants are indicated only for mild pain

questions.explanation:
The true statement is the use of morphine falls under step 3 of WHO analgesic ladder for chronic 
pain in adults. WHO has developed 3 step ladder for chronic/cancer pain relief in adults. The 3 main principles are as follows: • By the clock: Drugs should be given “by the clock” or “around the clock” rather than 
“on-demand”. • By the mouth: The oral route is preferred. If not feasible, the least invasive route should be 
considered. • By the ladder: Drugs are given in the following order, Non-opioids  Mild opioids  Strong 
opioids. Adjuvants are added at any stage of the WHO ladder to relieve anxiety. Note: This 3-step ladder approach is inexpensive and 80-90% effective when utilized optimally. 370 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: You prescribe a cough syrup to a patient that has an opioid cough suppressant as one of the 
constituents. Which would be the opioid present in the syrup?
questions.explanation:
Codeine (methyl morphine) is an opioid used in the treatment of cough. It is a more selective cough suppressant than morphine and widely used as an antitussive agent. It 
has antitussive actions at subanalgesic doses. The analgesic action of codeine is mainly due to its conversion to morphine.

questions.question: Question 21: How does dextromethorphan differ from codeine?
questions.explanation:
Dextromethorphan causes fewer gastrointestinal side effects like constipation when compared 
with codeine. It is a synthetic central NMDA (N-methyl D-aspartate) receptor antagonist. It is used as an antitussive agent and has no analgesic property. Option A: The antitussive action of dextromethorphan is not blocked by naloxone. Option B: Dextromethorphan does not depress the mucociliary function of the airway mucosa. Option C: It has no addictive property. 371 
Sold by @itachibot Synthetic Opioids
